content.body: Justin Ridgewell: Args being implicitly public works reasonably well in Python, imxp. (And you can now dictate that some args are positional-only and not available by name.) Or is the concern just that exposing arg name of *existing* functions, predating such a syntax, would be a problem?
content.formatted_body: Justin Ridgewell: Args being implicitly public works reasonably well in Python, imxp. (And you can now dictate that some args are positional-only and not available by name.) Or is the concern just that exposing arg name of existing functions, predating such a syntax, would be a problem?

content.body: My worry would be libraries who are unaware, but users who are.
JS devs don’t currently need to think about it, and so it’s normal for it to change without updating the major.
Additionally, what if the lib went through a minifier? What are the public names now?
And what will they be the next time it’s run though?
Terser uses char frequency to select mangled names. A completely unrelated code change in a string can cause the mangled name in a function to change.
I think if JS did add actual named parameters, you would have to opt-in somehow.
